I had to teach myself that. I had to learn to love myself again. See I didn't have what you would call a conventional childhood‚Ä¶

I was sexually abused from the age of 6 till about 10, by a close family member. Yep I know.

Probably not what you were expecting to read on someones Linkedin Bio.

This destroys your trust in people and relationships, and my abuser would often try to commit suicide. Whilst I was left in the house with them.

So I escaped into stories, to try and understand what had happened to me.

Trauma strips you of your voice and it snatches away childhood. I want to teach people how to be creative again (just like a children are) and empower them through that to find their digital voice.

Stories let you escape to a place of safety. And when you're confronted with that as a kid, that‚Äôs exactly what you do. 

You dive into your imagination‚Ä¶ Telling stories and creativity is as natural to me as breathing. It‚Äôs my gift and it makes me unique.
Don‚Äôt worry this particular story does have a happy ending.

I would have never have met my incredible wife and had two amazing children if it wasn‚Äôt for what happened to me as a boy. So for that I‚Äôm thankful.

And with time I have forgiven that little boy and myself, and it‚Äôs shaped me, my business and my life.

Inside each and every one of us is a story waiting to be told, one that defines who you are.

It‚Äôs your digital voice waiting to become it, it‚Äôs that tiny sound inside you that you wish you could silence. It‚Äôs your story waiting to get out, this is what makes you unique and one of a kind.

I have already traveled this path.

Changing the stories we tell about ourselves allows us to change the world around us for good. If I can tell my story, you can too.

It‚Äôs this story which will allow you to cross the digital divide, an increasing gap between traditional business models and a new creator led economy.

Just a guy, changing the world, 1 person, 1 team and 1 company at a time. 
Through social storytelling.

As a kid I was also -

Hit by a swing, run over by a car ‚Ä®and electrocuted. 
Which explains a lot! üòÇ

Everyone can be a creator, yes even you!

Let‚Äôs change your story so we can change the world ‚ò∫Ô∏è

ü§ù DM Me 

PS I also ‚ù§Ô∏è videogames

A Digital Renaissance Man at heart

Your creative spirit animal ü¶ä

Contact deets
‚úâÔ∏è nick@vireal.media
https://calendly.com/thatsocialnerd

Check out my PDF guides, in the featured sectionüëÜ END

After I met this coach, I learned that human connections are one of the best ways of knowing what people want and seeing if what you provide can help them or not. 

THE SOLUTION: Done right, conversations can help you build relationships. Relationships can help you get sales. Sales can help you test your offer for proof of concept, understand the problems your dream clients are facing on a deeper level, and ace your messaging.

completion:
Want to get to know me? Here's a few things you should know:

For the last 10 yrs I've made my living as a sales professional (and now trainer) and while I never imagined myself in this career, I've found the art of sales to be a fascinating craft and one that has led me to become a better version of myself. On my journey to sales mastery I've become a better listener, more empathetic, a more creative thinker, more emotionally resilient, and gotten even clearer on my values. 

I believe sales is a craft that can be mastered in the same ways that others are mastered. Rather than being a matter of "you've either 'got it' or you don't", I have found that success in sales is a matter of mastering a number of specific skills through deliberate practice. In fact, I believe this so strongly that I co-founded The Practice Lab as a place where sellers can gather to hone their craft in the same way masters of other disciplines hone theirs. 

In recent years I've come to recognize just how many privileges I have in life, and feel strongly my responsibility to use those privileges in the service of those who do not have them. This has led me to get involved in supporting a number of social justice causes with my time, words, and actions. 

Both in personal and professional contexts I believe in honest, authentic, and even vulnerable relationships. This affects how I work with colleagues, how I show up in my online content, the transparency and candor I bring into sales interactions, and everything in between. 

I have a wife and three kids and work a lot so I really don't have a ton of hobbies outside of hanging out with them. However, I live in the beautiful state of Colorado and make it a point to get out and go hiking at least once a month. That's where I go to take care of my mental health when life starts to wear me down. 

Think we could be friends? Shoot me a connection request and let's see where it leads us! END

If you've written something with a strong message, you can't afford to just hope it's right. Can you?

üíª Proofreading is the final polish to your document to catch any mistakes. I check for: sense, language (spelling, punctuation, grammar), style consistency (capitalisation, headings, date format), accuracy, missing words, URLs and more! 

üíª Proof-editing is ideal if you want more than a traditional proofread but not a deep or developmental edit. If time and budget don't allow for an editor and a proofreader, this is a great solution for improving readability.

completion:
I had a "friend" who burnt out early in his advertising career. 

Okay fine, it was me.

It wasn't just the hours. It was the hard hours, working under pressure while simultaneously doubting myself as a creative and feeling alone in that struggle. No awards or promotions could take it away.

Now, in between client work, I try to help people with this, including myself. And I think we get there by focusing on three things:

Have a confident and creative day. END

prompt:
Write a unique LinkedIn bio that is minimum 1200 characters and maximum 2600 characters long. Use native-level English.

###
completion:
Hi, I'm Angelique Hersman. I translate your texts from English into Dutch. 

Over the past eight years, I have translated all kinds of texts, from corporate business information to PiLs for clinical trials and everything in between. For instance, one of my recent translation assignments was a presentation on how to use a specific psychological test. I translated the presentation in such a way that people were not distracted by all kinds of expensive terms. This made it easier for the reader to consume all the insights offered.

Looking back, it was pretty clear which way this was going. As an example, I really enjoyed translating veterinary topics. And I translated remarkably much on Human Resources and employee satisfaction. Logically, these two areas suit me well; I trained and volunteered as a veterinary assistant and livestock farmer, and I am currently studying organisational psychology.

What really stood out? The dozens, almost hundreds of Safety Data Sheets I have translated over the past few years. To do that well, I put in many hours of research. The same has been the case with clinical trial documentation and patient-side information.

Some strict protocols and instructions must be followed meticulously for these documents. It is also a must that you are and stay abreast of current European legislation in that area. It turns out that this is where my strength lies. I am a whiz at (literature) research, finding my answers in every nook and cranny of the global internet and not being fobbed off with superficial gibberish. And without a source reference, it doesn't even count.

What can I do for you?

I translate your English texts into Dutch. While doing that, I ensure that this translated text sounds catchy and natural, so the reader feels addressed. Where necessary, I adapt it to our national preferences. For example, we Dutch are really unhappy with the typical English writing style. "Geen woorden maar daden" (actions speak louder than words), we are quick to say in undiluted Rotterdam style.

Although I have a broad general interest, there are areas in which my qualities come into their own. For instance, they require specific skills, such as tightly regulated documents or experience. 

My translation skills come to their fullest in projects in:

‚úî Veterinary and animal health
‚úî Healthcare, medical care and documentation for clinical trials (PILs, ICFs and SmPCs)
‚úî Human resources and HS&E, and the previously discussed Safety Data Sheets. END

###
completion:
I do many things. Some of them I am actually good at. So good I get paid to do them.
Short version would say ‚ÄúI write words in English, Spanish and Catalan to help you get more customers‚Äù. Luckily enough, LinkedIn lets me go into further detail. üëá

HOW CAN THIS SPANISH, WEIRD, LONG-HAIRED MAN HELP YOU

In many ways. Most of them are related to writing. 

We should probably check first if any of them are actually helpful to you. Are you one of these?

‚óºÔ∏è You run a business and want to expand it to the Spanish market.
‚óºÔ∏è You run a content agency and need content created in English, Spanish or Catalan.
‚óºÔ∏è You wrote a book and want it to reach a Spanish-speaking audience.

You are? Good. Then I can help you grow your business doing this:

üñäÔ∏è Copywriting in English, Spanish and Catalan
üñäÔ∏è Content writing in English, Spanish and Catalan
üñäÔ∏è Transcreation (AKA Creative Translation) from English to Spanish and Catalan

You're probably familiar with the first two. They're often presented like this:

I write words so you get more traffic.
I write words so you build your authority.
I write words so you get more sales.
I write words so you don't have to.

But...

WHAT THE F*** IS TRANSCREATION?

I wrote a post about it. It's on my Featured section down below. But I'll summarise it for you here:

üëâ Transcreation is what a bilingual copywriter does when a translated text loses its mojo.

I'm a copywriter. I'm bilingual. I've done plenty of translation work in the past. And I've seen some baaaaaaad Spanish versions of website copy, ads and videogames.

Don't get me wrong. The translations were fine. They were accurate, well-written and sounded natural. That's what a translator does. 

But they didn't take the target audience into consideration. They didn't elicit the same emotion. They didn't convince customers to take action. And that's what a copywriter is supposed to do.

If you merge those two, you get a transcreator. You could see them as copywriters who can write comfortably in two languages. Or translators who are willing to rip your originals apart and build something from scratch.

Or as someone who can help you be a star abroad.

If you're thinking of getting more Spanish love and customers, e-mails make me happy.

üôÉ hola@vicgimenez.com END

completion:

Do you know why it's the "people's" choice, not the "peoples' " choice?

How about using I, me, or myself ... or a semicolon? Do you know the rules for those?

The writing world is a wondrous place, and whether you call yourself a blogger, author, writer, or ghostwriter, you‚Äôre writing for public consumption. You‚Äôre writing content you hope impresses others. 

‚úî You could be looking for a job.

‚úî You could be writing a nonfiction / business-related book -- or even a memoir! 

‚ùì But do your presentations show your (or your clients') ideas to full advantage?

How could you possibly have known then how important all that would be to you as an adult, as a professional?

As a content creator, my motto is ◊¥If it doesn‚Äôt offer anything of value, I‚Äôm not writing it◊¥.

That might sound simplistic, but thanks in part to being an extremely busy mom, I‚Äôm a real straight-talker, so it makes sense that this is exactly the kind of attitude I bring to my professional work.

Everything I write, I create not only to entertain, inform, or engage ‚Äì but to make my readers‚Äô lives easier. 

Our lovely readers at AppsFlyer are primarily marketers, and so everything I write for them is geared to hit them with the information they really need to know about our hyper-dynamic industry ‚Äì the constant changes, the expectations, and the innovations that will be important for them to know in their day-to-day work. Writing in a way that grabs attention, holds it, and makes my readers look at things in a new light is what I do best.

For 15 years in my earlier career (I know, I don‚Äôt look old enough), I worked as an account executive in B2B. I learned a lot in that time about what it meant to really listen to my clients. I researched their business, I zoned in on their pain points, and then put together a solution that met their problems head-on. 

I know some people are born to sell, but even though I was good at it, it drained me from my very core. My real joy has always laid in content creation. Combining the dying art form of listening with ample research and my love of writing, meant that I knew I was well placed to create some really special stuff for some really special people.

I guess AppsFlyer saw this in me, and now almost 2 years into working at this stellar company, I write everything from delicious blogs, goodies-packed guides and data-rich reports, to sparkling web copy, irresistible email sequences and punchy social media campaigns.

I‚Äôm not one of those people who blows smoke up the ass of their employer to put themselves firmly at the front line when they‚Äôre handing out pay rises, but when I know I‚Äôm onto a good thing ‚Äì I say it. 

I love working at AppsFlyer, because I get to do what I love and I get to do it around truly awesome, kind and talented people. With a genuine focus on customer happiness and employee wellbeing, I‚Äôm well looked after, as well as given everything I need to do the best possible job for our customers.

Away from work, my family is my rock and my safe space in any storm, but if I start writing about them, I‚Äôll never stop. 

So, let‚Äôs get back to work. END

completion:
At the age of 16, with 256 Kbps Internet speed, I started my career as a self-taught graphic designer. 

After landing a few projects, I was hungry to keep learning more, and that's how I landed in web development. 

At the age of 18, while still pursuing my education, I launched my first product around WordPress security, which did wonder. It not only paid for my entire education but helped me become financially independent as a teenager.

However, I exited that project and continued with my college and freelance development. 

At the age of 20, I met my first co-founder Oscar Hernandez (He has been my co-founder ever since in everything that we do), known as Power Up Hosting; I ran the company for over 7-years before exiting. 

At 24, I started India's first PBN Hosting platform, which I later exited in 2017. 

My life changed when I launched my third startup, which failed severely and changed my whole life. 

It taught me some of the most valuable life lessons, including management, team hiring, and more. 

The failure of my third startup gave me the idea of PitchGround (My most successful startup to date, currently valued at $20m as of 2022). PitchGround is a SaaS Marketplace that bridges the gap between early-stage SaaS companies and early adopters, small-medium-sized businesses. 

With over 92% of the SaaS companies failing in the first three years of their business, our mission was to resolve this unresolved market worth over $200 billion. 

During this journey, I met my second co-founder Lukas Liesis, building the company's core foundation. 

Launched PitchGround on the 25th of September 2018, PitchGround has done over $5m in sales as a bootstrapped company, something our entire team is proud of. 

PitchGround has helped hundreds of companies and has seen over 80% of companies succeeding who are launching with us, out of which 15% of the companies can successfully raise capital post launching their SaaS on our platform. 

At PitchGround, we firmly believe in our 3P philosophy for any founder who wants to achieve a product-market fit - Product, People & Pricing (Same format). 

In 2021, I started Angel Investment, and so far, I have invested in 24 startups; I mentor some of them to give back to the community. 

In 2022, I rebuilt my previous failure, known as https://firstsales.io, which is doing $500k ARR in just 5 months.

If you are a small business, do check out PitchGround and save up to 95% on your software bills - website link

Got any questions or want to connect with me? Please send me an email at email ID
 END
